facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1749 of 1966 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1749 of 1966.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated May 3, 1962 of Allahabad High Court in F.A.F.O. No. 330 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated May 3, 1962 of the Allahabad High Court in F.A.F.O. No. 330 of 1960.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court reversed order of Civil Judge setting aside an award.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal from the judgment dated 3rd May, 1962 passed by the High Court at Allahabad reversing the order of the Civil Judge setting aside an award.

facts.text: Appellant formerly known as Municipal Board, Kanpur and thereafter as Kanpur Nagar Mahapalika.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was formerly known as Municipal Board, Kanpur and thereafter as Kanpur Nagar Mahapalika.

facts.text: Appellant and respondent entered into a contract in writing for construction of zone pumping stations and reservoirs at Kanpur.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant in the former name of Municipal Board, Kanpur and the respondent entered into, a companytract in writing for companystruction of zone pumping stations and reservoirs at Kanpur.

facts.text: Contract contained an arbitration agreement between the parties.

anchor.surface_text: One of the clauses in the said agreement in writing companytained an arbitration agreement between the parties.

facts.text: Respondent filed original suit No. 45 of 1946 in Court of Civil and Sessions Judge, Kanpur against Municipal Board, Kanpur claiming Rs. 60,802-4-9 for balance sum due on final bills, interest, refund of security deposit and interest.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent filed original suit No. 45 of 1946 in the Court of Civil and Sessions Judge, Kanpur, against the Municipal Board, Kanpur and claimed a sum of Rs. 60, 802-4-9 representing the claims on account of balance sum due according to the final bills, interest on the amount due, refund of security deposit and interest thereon.

facts.text: Suit instituted in the year 1946.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was instituted in the year 1946.

facts.text: Municipal Board applied under section 34 of Arbitration Act, 1940 for stay of suit.

anchor.surface_text: The Municipal Board, Kanpur thereafter made an application under section 34 of the Arbitration Act, 1940 for stay of the suit companytending that the suit related to a matter agreed to be referred to arbitration.

facts.text: On 9th August, 1952, Court ordered stay of the proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: On 9th August, 1952, the Court ordered stay of the proceedings.

facts.text: Plaintiff preferred appeal against the stay order.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff preferred an appeal against the order.

facts.text: On 4th November, 1957, High Court directed Court to proceed with reference as appeal not pressed.

anchor.surface_text: By an order dated 4th November, 1957 the High Court at Allahabad directed that since the appeal was number pressed by the plaintiff the Court should proceed with the matter of reference.

facts.text: On 17th May, 1958, Court of Additional Civil Judge, Kanpur referred matter to Shri K. Roy, Superintending Engineer as arbitrator.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter on 17th May, 1958 the Court of Additional Civil Judge, Kanpur sent the matter to Shri K. Roy, Superintending Engineer, who was appointed an arbitrator on the reference.

facts.text: Arbitrator made award on 8th March, 1960 in favour of plaintiff for Rs. 42,772-2-9 on final bill, Rs. 9,705 on security deposit and interest thereon.

anchor.surface_text: The arbitrator on 8th March, 1960 made an award in favour of the plaintiff respondent for the sum of Rs. 42,772-2-9 on account of final bill, a sum of Rs. 9,705/- on account of refund of security deposit and interest on the security deposit.

facts.text: Appellant applied to set aside award alleging arbitrator misconducted by not properly considering claim barred by section 326 of U.P. Act 2 of 1916.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant thereafter made an application for setting aside the award on the ground that the arbitrator misconducted himself in the proceedings by number properly companysidering and deciding that the claim of the plaintiff was barred by section 326 of the U.P. Act 2 of 1916.

facts.text: Additional Civil Judge, Kanpur by judgment dated 31st May, 1960 set aside the award holding arbitrator wrongly decided limitation point and misconducted.

anchor.surface_text: The Additional Civil Judge, Kanpur by judgment dated 31st May, 1960 set aside the award by holding that the arbitrator wrongly decided the point of limitation and thereby misconducted himself.

facts.text: High Court reversed the setting aside of award.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal from the judgment dated 3rd May, 1962 passed by the High Court at Allahabad reversing the order of the Civil Judge setting aside an award.

facts.text: High Court held that arbitrator deciding limitation in favour of plaintiff not error of law apparent on face of award.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court came to the companyclusion that if the arbitrator had decided it in favour of the plaintiff and did number accept the prescribed period of limitation under section 326 of the Municipalities. Act, it would number be an error of law apparent on the face of the Award.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was companyrect in refusing to set aside the award. For the reasons mentioned above, the appeal fails and is dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: Award does not lay down any proposition of law on limitation or construe section 326.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the award does number lay down any proposition of law on the question of limitation. The award does number put any companystruction on section 326 of the Municipalities Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Award neither states nor incorporates any legal proposition on limitation as basis for decision; applies tests from Champsey Bhara and Dr. S. Dutt precedents requiring explicit erroneous legal basis on face.

holdings.text: It is sufficient if the arbitrator gives an award on the whole case and he need not deal with each issue separately. It was open to the arbitrator to decide on the rival contentions of the parties as to limitation.

anchor.surface_text: It is sufficient if the arbitrator gives an award on the whole case and he need not deal with each issue separately. It was open to the arbitrator to decide on the rival contentions of the parties as to limitation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Arbitrator's duty is to award on whole case; no requirement for separate findings on issues like limitation unless specified.

holdings.text: If an arbitrator makes a mistake either in law or on fact and if such mistake does not appear on the face of the award, the award will not be bad notwithstanding any mistake.

anchor.surface_text: In doing so, if an arbitrator makes a mistake either in law or on fact and if such mistake does not appear on the face of the award, the award will not be bad notwithstanding any mistake.

holdings.reasoning_summary: General principle derived from scope of court review in arbitration; errors not apparent on face immune from challenge.

holdings.text: We must not in the present case be understood to express any opinion that there was however any mistake.
